pull_request.title: fix: Invalid Date object will throw a TypeError (#58)
pull_request.body:
This PR will make sure that `loupe` will return `"Invalid Date"` if a `Date` object is invalid. It does **not** deal with _how_ the `Date` object became invalid as that depends on JS engine.

See https://github.com/chaijs/loupe/issues/58#issuecomment-1303259185 for a comparison between V8 and Firefox's SpiderMoney.

issue.title: fix: Invalid Date object will throw a TypeError (#58)
issue.body:
This PR will make sure that `loupe` will return `"Invalid Date"` if a `Date` object is invalid. It does **not** deal with _how_ the `Date` object became invalid as that depends on JS engine.

See https://github.com/chaijs/loupe/issues/58#issuecomment-1303259185 for a comparison between V8 and Firefox's SpiderMoney.

issue.title: Suggestion: improve date tooltip discoverability
issue.body:
See this twitter thread:

https://twitter.com/FlohOfWoe/status/1325427548650532864

Currently it's easy to miss the mouse-hover tooltip with the absolute time, especially in strings like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1699414/98466705-92d13e00-21d1-11eb-891c-71a8e99ec2e0.png)

The relative time "29 days ago" is fairly useless, it would be better to know the absolute date, which is hidden in a tooltip which is easy to miss (the date sub-string doesn't make it obvious that something will happen on mouse-hover, and the delay until the tooltip appears is way too long to discover it "by accident").

A visual clue like the dashed line here would do wonders for discoverability:

![EmTicPUWEAENOwM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1699414/98466785-06734b00-21d2-11eb-8ce2-b1a4e9cb8c3e.png)

comment.body: I'm going to close this as this issue tracker should be related to issues around the implementation of `relative-time`, not its use on GitHub.com. Of course if you're still finding this to be an issue please do contact `support@github.com`!

issue.title: With relative times, tooltip shows in browser language instead of document language
issue.body:
When using relative times, times older than a month are show absolutely, localized using the document's language (good!); however, the `title` is localized using the browser language (bad!). This should consistently use the document language.

https://github.com/github/time-elements/blob/4414cbacdb1e0cf95b7e99960897bb0c55736323/src/extended-time-element.ts#L64

comment.body: In `v3.2.0` they both now use the same way to determine the local; looking for the closest element with a `lang` attribute. So I believe this fixes the issue. Let me know if you run into any other issues.

comment.body: This is now supported in `v3.2.0` via the `lang` attribute. The element will find the nearest element that has a `lang` attribute and use that; so you can set it once on `<html lang="...">` and `<relative-time`> should respect that!

issue.title: datetime value not reflecting browser preferred locale?
issue.body:
Hi! I was testing this component today and noticed that the `title` attribute properly translates to my locale, but not the displayed value, which causes confusion. Looking at the examples page: https://github.github.io/time-elements/examples, this is what I see in my browser:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13930952/161117860-bed222a4-dd9c-4c09-8b57-30d47373a11b.png)

As you can see, the title is properly translated, but not the displayed value. This is the source from the page:

```
<local-time datetime="1970-01-01T00:00:00.000Z" weekday="short" year="numeric" month="short" day="numeric" hour="numeric" minute="2-digit" second="2-digit" title="31 de dez. de 1969 21:00 BRT">Wed 31 Dec 1969 21:00:00</local-time>
```

PS.: BTW, another thing that I'm trying to solve is that the component does not support something like `month="numeric"`, which is the most common way of displaying dates in my current locale.

issue.title: local-based defaults for local-time attributes?
issue.body:
I've overcome some earlier difficulties by changing my example usage be like the example HTML. I now have: ```html

Maintenance Window

The system may be down for 2 hours starting 2022-01-01T00:12:00.000Z ``` But the displayed result (in my Pacific time browser) says: >The system may be down for 2 hours starting Sat Jan 1, 2022 Using a ***local-time*** element, I would expect that formatting including the time of day would be the default. It also seems to me that needing to specify attributes like `day="numeric"` adds a lot of overhead to using this web component, but if I leave the attribute off, no day-of-month gets shown in the formatted result. It seems like there should be default values (preferably based on locale) for these attributes (perhaps with the exception of `datetime`.) As to the `datetime` attribute, it seems like the body text would be a reasonable default, so that I could simply say: ```html

The system may be down for 2 hours starting 2022-01-01T00:12:00.000Z ``` Am I missing some relevant point(s) here?

issue.title: relative-time - Hard-coded format for non-relative output
issue.body:
The element is pretty limited to English and the github date style right now.
There should be a way to supply a strftime format for anything that is too old to be displayed in relative terms.

For example:
https://github.com/github/time-elements/blob/77a086c07630ae2fefb1a763a2d5212b72de79d2/src/relative-time.js#L23

issue.title: Custom prefix for relative-time
issue.body:
I noticed that for `<relative-time>` which is further than 1 month ago we show example: `on 14 April 2018`

Would it be possible to add custom prefix, which if not specified would default to `on` (for backwards compatibility) but in case I could specify empty string so I would get just `14 April 2018`?

issue.title: Custom prefix for relative-time
issue.body:
I noticed that for `<relative-time>` which is further than 1 month ago we show example: `on 14 April 2018`

Would it be possible to add custom prefix, which if not specified would default to `on` (for backwards compatibility) but in case I could specify empty string so I would get just `14 April 2018`?

comment.body: This is now possible with the `prefix` attribute, which defaults to `'on'` but can be set to `''` to remove the prefix.

issue.title: Override content for local-time and default formatting
issue.body:
I found 2 problems: appending content in chrome and no default formatting

**No default formatting:**

Source:
```html
<local-time datetime="2018-08-24T16:57:42.604Z">Aug 24, 2018 23:57:42</local-time>
```
Result:
```html
<local-time datetime="2018-08-24T16:57:42.604Z" title="Aug 24, 2018, 11:57 PM GMT+7">Aug 24, 2018 23:57:42</local-time>
```
would be much easier to start if it would apply default formatting `month="short" day="numeric" year="numeric" hour="numeric" minute="numeric"` (or similar) and may be `update-content=false` to prevent updating content

**Appending content in chrome:**
Source:
```html
<local-time datetime="2014-04-01T16:30:00-08:00" month="short" day="numeric" year="numeric" hour="numeric" minute="numeric">April 1, 2014 4:30PM PDT</local-time>
```
Result:
```html
<local-time datetime="2014-04-01T16:30:00-08:00" month="short" day="numeric" year="numeric" hour="numeric" minute="numeric" title="Apr 2, 2014, 7:30 AM GMT+7">Apr 2, 2014 7:30 AMApril 1, 2014 4:30PM PDT</local-time>
```

issue.title: Expose time formatting
issue.body: The source code contains an implementation of `strftime` and a few functions that use it but there's no way to access it directly. It would be nice if you could use it to customize the format of the `title` attribute and other strings.

comment.body: `3.2.0` now has a `format` attribute which can take a `strftime` value.

issue.title: time-ago wrong calcul
issue.body:
For current date 2015-02-23T00:00:00.000Z (like)

The following html :
<time is="time-ago" format="micro" datetime="1900-02-01T00:00:00.000Z">

Give this result : 
<time is="time-ago" format="micro" datetime="1900-02-01T00:00:00.000Z" title="Feb 1, 1900, 12:09 AM GMT+0:09:21">117y</time>

Or it's should give 115 or maybe 116 not 117 !

Note : for date 002-02-01T00:00:00.000Z It's even more obvious.

release.name: v3.2.0
release.body:
## What's Changed
This release includes a large rewrite of the component with many new features that allow for fine-grained control over the display of the date. Existing uses will work as they always have, but a set of new attributes provide detailed control about how dates get rendered!


* Update README.md by @josepmartins in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/171
* Fix closing tag for `time-until` in documentation by @meduzen in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/172
* move AOR to primer by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/173
* fix lang on relative-time day ordering by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/175
* Custom format by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/177
* switch from karma to web-test-runner by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/178
* Use esbuild by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/179
* Split strftime out by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/180
* add tense to relative-time by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/181
* simplify time-until/ago elements by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/182
* Extract tostring from relative time into element by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/183
* Add threshold by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/184
* Refactor relative time by @koddsson in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/185
* Inline utilities only used in `<relative-time>` by @koddsson in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/186
* Inline extended time element into relative time by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/187
* add relative-time tests for local-time by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/188
* add setters for all attributes by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/189
* RelativeTimeElement: Progressive time update intervals by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/190
* Add custome elements manifest by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/191
* Switch element to defining content within ShadowDOM by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/193
* Update readme by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/192
* Local time refactor by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/194
* add tests for ponyfills by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/195
* refactor relative-time to remove RelativeTimeFormat by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/196
* inline utils functions by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/197
* Make duration class by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/198
* Minor cleanups by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/199

## New Contributors
* @josepmartins made their first contribution in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/171
* @meduzen made their first contribution in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/172

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/compare/v3.1.4...v3.2.0

pull_request.title: fix: Invalid Date object will throw a TypeError (#58)
pull_request.body:
This PR will make sure that `loupe` will return `"Invalid Date"` if a `Date` object is invalid. It does **not** deal with _how_ the `Date` object became invalid as that depends on JS engine.

See https://github.com/chaijs/loupe/issues/58#issuecomment-1303259185 for a comparison between V8 and Firefox's SpiderMoney.

pull_request.title: Make duration class
pull_request.body:
This refactors our `duration.ts` file to include a class which aligns closer to Temporal.Duration. In fact I even added `@js-temporal/polyfill` as a devdependency and ran some tests comparing our `Duration` class to the `Temporal.Duration` class.

This is useful because `threshold` can be set to a string that `Temporal.Duration.from` would take, and so the closer we align to that the better. Additionally, the closer our class is to `Temporal.Duration`, the easier it'll be to delete it one day.

pull_request.title: refactor relative-time to remove RelativeTimeFormat
pull_request.body: This extracts out the coupling of `RelativeTimeFormat` from our `RelativeTime` class - which now instead returns a tuple of `number, Unit`, reflecting just the rounded unit of time that should be rendered. This allows us to subsequently refactor the `RelativeTime` class closer to the proposed web platform primitive Temporal.Duration, which will come in a follow up PR :smile:

Local time refactor

pull_request.title: Local time refactor
pull_request.body:
This PR introduces a `DateTimeFormat` ponyfill, which allows us to drop it in place of `Intl.DateTimeFormat`. This then allowed a larger refactor where we can drop parts of the codebase where we emulated `DateTimeFormat` behavior using strftime. Instead, the ponyfill does that and the `relative-time` and `local-time` code can be greatly simplified.

I think in the major version release, we should drop both the `DateTimeFormat` and `RelativeTime` ponyfills as these are very well supported in evergreen browsers. (`DateTimeFormat` works back to IE11 & Safari 10, while `RelativeTime` works back to Safari 14)

Switch element to defining content within ShadowDOM

pull_request.title: Switch element to defining content within ShadowDOM
pull_request.body:
This changes the `<relative-time>` element to use a ShadowRoot, instead of mutating the `textContent` directly. This is useful because it enables `<relative-time>` to mutate its own display without interfering with components or frameworks which assess or otherwise depend on the tree below `<relative-time>`; for example frameworks like React which maintain a virtual DOM, or code which leverages Mutation Observers to track changes to the tree.

The trade-off here is that it is not possible to assert the display of the date via `el.textContent`, as this would represent the light HTML tree (so likely the original date rendered server side). Consequently the tests need to change to accommodate this.

issue.title: Suggestion: improve date tooltip discoverability
issue.body:
See this twitter thread:

https://twitter.com/FlohOfWoe/status/1325427548650532864

Currently it's easy to miss the mouse-hover tooltip with the absolute time, especially in strings like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1699414/98466705-92d13e00-21d1-11eb-891c-71a8e99ec2e0.png)

The relative time "29 days ago" is fairly useless, it would be better to know the absolute date, which is hidden in a tooltip which is easy to miss (the date sub-string doesn't make it obvious that something will happen on mouse-hover, and the delay until the tooltip appears is way too long to discover it "by accident").

A visual clue like the dashed line here would do wonders for discoverability:

![EmTicPUWEAENOwM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1699414/98466785-06734b00-21d2-11eb-8ce2-b1a4e9cb8c3e.png)

issue.title: With relative times, tooltip shows in browser language instead of document language
issue.body:
When using relative times, times older than a month are show absolutely, localized using the document's language (good!); however, the `title` is localized using the browser language (bad!). This should consistently use the document language.

https://github.com/github/time-elements/blob/4414cbacdb1e0cf95b7e99960897bb0c55736323/src/extended-time-element.ts#L64

issue.title: datetime value not reflecting browser preferred locale?
issue.body:
Hi! I was testing this component today and noticed that the `title` attribute properly translates to my locale, but not the displayed value, which causes confusion. Looking at the examples page: https://github.github.io/time-elements/examples, this is what I see in my browser:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13930952/161117860-bed222a4-dd9c-4c09-8b57-30d47373a11b.png)

As you can see, the title is properly translated, but not the displayed value. This is the source from the page:

```
<local-time datetime="1970-01-01T00:00:00.000Z" weekday="short" year="numeric" month="short" day="numeric" hour="numeric" minute="2-digit" second="2-digit" title="31 de dez. de 1969 21:00 BRT">Wed 31 Dec 1969 21:00:00</local-time>
```

PS.: BTW, another thing that I'm trying to solve is that the component does not support something like `month="numeric"`, which is the most common way of displaying dates in my current locale.

issue.title: local-based defaults for local-time attributes?
issue.body:
I've overcome some earlier difficulties by changing my example usage be like the example HTML. I now have: ```html

Maintenance Window

The system may be down for 2 hours starting 2022-01-01T00:12:00.000Z ``` But the displayed result (in my Pacific time browser) says: >The system may be down for 2 hours starting Sat Jan 1, 2022 Using a ***local-time*** element, I would expect that formatting including the time of day would be the default. It also seems to me that needing to specify attributes like `day="numeric"` adds a lot of overhead to using this web component, but if I leave the attribute off, no day-of-month gets shown in the formatted result. It seems like there should be default values (preferably based on locale) for these attributes (perhaps with the exception of `datetime`.) As to the `datetime` attribute, it seems like the body text would be a reasonable default, so that I could simply say: ```html

The system may be down for 2 hours starting 2022-01-01T00:12:00.000Z ``` Am I missing some relevant point(s) here?

issue.title: Custom prefix for relative-time
issue.body:
I noticed that for `<relative-time>` which is further than 1 month ago we show example: `on 14 April 2018`

Would it be possible to add custom prefix, which if not specified would default to `on` (for backwards compatibility) but in case I could specify empty string so I would get just `14 April 2018`?

I noticed that for `<relative-time>` which is further than 1 month ago we show example: `on 14 April 2018`

Would it be possible to add custom prefix, which if not specified would default to `on` (for backwards compatibility) but in case I could specify empty string so I would get just `14 April 2018`?

comment.body: This is now possible with the `prefix` attribute, which defaults to `'on'` but can be set to `''` to remove the prefix.

issue.title: Override content for local-time and default formatting
issue.body:
I found 2 problems: appending content in chrome and no default formatting

**No default formatting:**

Source:
```html
<local-time datetime="2018-08-24T16:57:42.604Z">Aug 24, 2018 23:57:42</local-time>
```
Result:
```html
<local-time datetime="2018-08-24T16:57:42.604Z" title="Aug 24, 2018, 11:57 PM GMT+7">Aug 24, 2018 23:57:42</local-time>
```
would be much easier to start if it would apply default formatting `month="short" day="numeric" year="numeric" hour="numeric" minute="numeric"` (or similar) and may be `update-content=false` to prevent updating content

**Appending content in chrome:**
Source:
```html
<local-time datetime="2014-04-01T16:30:00-08:00" month="short" day="numeric" year="numeric" hour="numeric" minute="numeric">April 1, 2014 4:30PM PDT</local-time>
```
Result:
```html
<local-time datetime="2014-04-01T16:30:00-08:00" month="short" day="numeric" year="numeric" hour="numeric" minute="numeric" title="Apr 2, 2014, 7:30 AM GMT+7">Apr 2, 2014 7:30 AMApril 1, 2014 4:30PM PDT</local-time>
```

release.name: v3.2.0
release.body:
## What's Changed
This release includes a large rewrite of the component with many new features that allow for fine-grained control over the display of the date. Existing uses will work as they always have, but a set of new attributes provide detailed control about how dates get rendered!


* Update README.md by @josepmartins in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/171
* Fix closing tag for `time-until` in documentation by @meduzen in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/172
* move AOR to primer by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/173
* fix lang on relative-time day ordering by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/175
* Custom format by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/177
* switch from karma to web-test-runner by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/178
* Use esbuild by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/179
* Split strftime out by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/180
* add tense to relative-time by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/181
* simplify time-until/ago elements by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/182
* Extract tostring from relative time into element by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/183
* Add threshold by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/184
* Refactor relative time by @koddsson in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/185
* Inline utilities only used in `<relative-time>` by @koddsson in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/186
* Inline extended time element into relative time by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/187
* add relative-time tests for local-time by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/188
* add setters for all attributes by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/189
* RelativeTimeElement: Progressive time update intervals by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/190
* Add custome elements manifest by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/191
* Switch element to defining content within ShadowDOM by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/193
* Update readme by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/192
* Local time refactor by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/194
* add tests for ponyfills by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/195
* refactor relative-time to remove RelativeTimeFormat by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/196
* inline utils functions by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/197
* Make duration class by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/198
* Minor cleanups by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/199

## New Contributors
* @josepmartins made their first contribution in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/171
* @meduzen made their first contribution in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/172

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/compare/v3.1.4...v3.2.0

pull_request.title: fix: Invalid Date object will throw a TypeError (#58)
pull_request.body:
This PR will make sure that `loupe` will return `"Invalid Date"` if a `Date` object is invalid. It does **not** deal with _how_ the `Date` object became invalid as that depends on JS engine.

See https://github.com/chaijs/loupe/issues/58#issuecomment-1303259185 for a comparison between V8 and Firefox's SpiderMoney.

pull_request.title: Make duration class
pull_request.body:
This refactors our `duration.ts` file to include a class which aligns closer to Temporal.Duration. In fact I even added `@js-temporal/polyfill` as a devdependency and ran some tests comparing our `Duration` class to the `Temporal.Duration` class.

This is useful because `threshold` can be set to a string that `Temporal.Duration.from` would take, and so the closer we align to that the better. Additionally, the closer our class is to `Temporal.Duration`, the easier it'll be to delete it one day.

Local time refactor

pull_request.title: Local time refactor
pull_request.body:
This PR introduces a `DateTimeFormat` ponyfill, which allows us to drop it in place of `Intl.DateTimeFormat`. This then allowed a larger refactor where we can drop parts of the codebase where we emulated `DateTimeFormat` behavior using strftime. Instead, the ponyfill does that and the `relative-time` and `local-time` code can be greatly simplified.

I think in the major version release, we should drop both the `DateTimeFormat` and `RelativeTime` ponyfills as these are very well supported in evergreen browsers. (`DateTimeFormat` works back to IE11 & Safari 10, while `RelativeTime` works back to Safari 14)

Merge pull request #193 from github/use-shadowdom

Switch element to defining content within ShadowDOM

pull_request.title: Switch element to defining content within ShadowDOM
pull_request.body:
This changes the `<relative-time>` element to use a ShadowRoot, instead of mutating the `textContent` directly. This is useful because it enables `<relative-time>` to mutate its own display without interfering with components or frameworks which assess or otherwise depend on the tree below `<relative-time>`; for example frameworks like React which maintain a virtual DOM, or code which leverages Mutation Observers to track changes to the tree.

The trade-off here is that it is not possible to assert the display of the date via `el.textContent`, as this would represent the light HTML tree (so likely the original date rendered server side). Consequently the tests need to change to accommodate this.

issue.title: Suggestion: improve date tooltip discoverability
issue.body:
See this twitter thread:

https://twitter.com/FlohOfWoe/status/1325427548650532864

Currently it's easy to miss the mouse-hover tooltip with the absolute time, especially in strings like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1699414/98466705-92d13e00-21d1-11eb-891c-71a8e99ec2e0.png)

The relative time "29 days ago" is fairly useless, it would be better to know the absolute date, which is hidden in a tooltip which is easy to miss (the date sub-string doesn't make it obvious that something will happen on mouse-hover, and the delay until the tooltip appears is way too long to discover it "by accident").

A visual clue like the dashed line here would do wonders for discoverability:

![EmTicPUWEAENOwM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1699414/98466785-06734b00-21d2-11eb-8ce2-b1a4e9cb8c3e.png)

issue.title: With relative times, tooltip shows in browser language instead of document language
issue.body:
When using relative times, times older than a month are show absolutely, localized using the document's language (good!); however, the `title` is localized using the browser language (bad!). This should consistently use the document language.

https://github.com/github/time-elements/blob/4414cbacdb1e0cf95b7e99960897bb0c55736323/src/extended-time-element.ts#L64

issue.title: datetime value not reflecting browser preferred locale?
issue.body:
Hi! I was testing this component today and noticed that the `title` attribute properly translates to my locale, but not the displayed value, which causes confusion. Looking at the examples page: https://github.github.io/time-elements/examples, this is what I see in my browser:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13930952/161117860-bed222a4-dd9c-4c09-8b57-30d47373a11b.png)

As you can see, the title is properly translated, but not the displayed value. This is the source from the page:

```
<local-time datetime="1970-01-01T00:00:00.000Z" weekday="short" year="numeric" month="short" day="numeric" hour="numeric" minute="2-digit" second="2-digit" title="31 de dez. de 1969 21:00 BRT">Wed 31 Dec 1969 21:00:00</local-time>
```

PS.: BTW, another thing that I'm trying to solve is that the component does not support something like `month="numeric"`, which is the most common way of displaying dates in my current locale.

issue.title: datetime value not reflecting browser preferred locale?
issue.body:
Hi! I was testing this component today and noticed that the `title` attribute properly translates to my locale, but not the displayed value, which causes confusion. Looking at the examples page: https://github.github.io/time-elements/examples, this is what I see in my browser:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13930952/161117860-bed222a4-dd9c-4c09-8b57-30d47373a11b.png)

As you can see, the title is properly translated, but not the displayed value. This is the source from the page:

```
<local-time datetime="1970-01-01T00:00:00.000Z" weekday="short" year="numeric" month="short" day="numeric" hour="numeric" minute="2-digit" second="2-digit" title="31 de dez. de 1969 21:00 BRT">Wed 31 Dec 1969 21:00:00</local-time>
```

PS.: BTW, another thing that I'm trying to solve is that the component does not support something like `month="numeric"`, which is the most common way of displaying dates in my current locale.

comment.body: If you'd like to try the new release, I believe it has support for languages supported by the browser. Let me know your thoughts and if you have any more ideas on what we could do here.

issue.title: local-based defaults for local-time attributes?
issue.body:
I've overcome some earlier difficulties by changing my example usage be like the example HTML. I now have: ```html

Maintenance Window

The system may be down for 2 hours starting 2022-01-01T00:12:00.000Z ``` But the displayed result (in my Pacific time browser) says: >The system may be down for 2 hours starting Sat Jan 1, 2022 Using a ***local-time*** element, I would expect that formatting including the time of day would be the default. It also seems to me that needing to specify attributes like `day="numeric"` adds a lot of overhead to using this web component, but if I leave the attribute off, no day-of-month gets shown in the formatted result. It seems like there should be default values (preferably based on locale) for these attributes (perhaps with the exception of `datetime`.) As to the `datetime` attribute, it seems like the body text would be a reasonable default, so that I could simply say: ```html

The system may be down for 2 hours starting 2022-01-01T00:12:00.000Z ``` Am I missing some relevant point(s) here?

issue.title: Custom prefix for relative-time
issue.body:
I noticed that for `<relative-time>` which is further than 1 month ago we show example: `on 14 April 2018`

Would it be possible to add custom prefix, which if not specified would default to `on` (for backwards compatibility) but in case I could specify empty string so I would get just `14 April 2018`?

issue.title: Custom prefix for relative-time
issue.body:
I noticed that for `<relative-time>` which is further than 1 month ago we show example: `on 14 April 2018`

Would it be possible to add custom prefix, which if not specified would default to `on` (for backwards compatibility) but in case I could specify empty string so I would get just `14 April 2018`?

comment.body: This is now possible with the `prefix` attribute, which defaults to `'on'` but can be set to `''` to remove the prefix.

issue.title: Override content for local-time and default formatting
issue.body:
I found 2 problems: appending content in chrome and no default formatting

**No default formatting:**

Source:
```html
<local-time datetime="2018-08-24T16:57:42.604Z">Aug 24, 2018 23:57:42</local-time>
```
Result:
```html
<local-time datetime="2018-08-24T16:57:42.604Z" title="Aug 24, 2018, 11:57 PM GMT+7">Aug 24, 2018 23:57:42</local-time>
```
would be much easier to start if it would apply default formatting `month="short" day="numeric" year="numeric" hour="numeric" minute="numeric"` (or similar) and may be `update-content=false` to prevent updating content

**Appending content in chrome:**
Source:
```html
<local-time datetime="2014-04-01T16:30:00-08:00" month="short" day="numeric" year="numeric" hour="numeric" minute="numeric">April 1, 2014 4:30PM PDT</local-time>
```
Result:
```html
<local-time datetime="2014-04-01T16:30:00-08:00" month="short" day="numeric" year="numeric" hour="numeric" minute="numeric" title="Apr 2, 2014, 7:30 AM GMT+7">Apr 2, 2014 7:30 AMApril 1, 2014 4:30PM PDT</local-time>
```

release.name: v3.2.0
release.body:
## What's Changed
This release includes a large rewrite of the component with many new features that allow for fine-grained control over the display of the date. Existing uses will work as they always have, but a set of new attributes provide detailed control about how dates get rendered!


* Update README.md by @josepmartins in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/171
* Fix closing tag for `time-until` in documentation by @meduzen in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/172
* move AOR to primer by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/173
* fix lang on relative-time day ordering by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/175
* Custom format by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/177
* switch from karma to web-test-runner by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/178
* Use esbuild by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/179
* Split strftime out by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/180
* add tense to relative-time by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/181
* simplify time-until/ago elements by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/182
* Extract tostring from relative time into element by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/183
* Add threshold by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/184
* Refactor relative time by @koddsson in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/185
* Inline utilities only used in `<relative-time>` by @koddsson in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/186
* Inline extended time element into relative time by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/187
* add relative-time tests for local-time by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/188
* add setters for all attributes by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/189
* RelativeTimeElement: Progressive time update intervals by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/190
* Add custome elements manifest by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/191
* Switch element to defining content within ShadowDOM by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/193
* Update readme by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/192
* Local time refactor by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/194
* add tests for ponyfills by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/195
* refactor relative-time to remove RelativeTimeFormat by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/196
* inline utils functions by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/197
* Make duration class by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/198
* Minor cleanups by @keithamus in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/199

## New Contributors
* @josepmartins made their first contribution in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/171
* @meduzen made their first contribution in https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/pull/172

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/github/relative-time-element/compare/v3.1.4...v3.2.0

pull_request.body:
This PR will make sure that `loupe` will return `"Invalid Date"` if a `Date` object is invalid. It does **not** deal with _how_ the `Date` object became invalid as that depends on JS engine.

See https://github.com/chaijs/loupe/issues/58#issuecomment-1303259185 for a comparison between V8 and Firefox's SpiderMoney.

pull_request.title: Make duration class
pull_request.body:
This refactors our `duration.ts` file to include a class which aligns closer to Temporal.Duration. In fact I even added `@js-temporal/polyfill` as a devdependency and ran some tests comparing our `Duration` class to the `Temporal.Duration` class.

This is useful because `threshold` can be set to a string that `Temporal.Duration.from` would take, and so the closer we align to that the better. Additionally, the closer our class is to `Temporal.Duration`, the easier it'll be to delete it one day.

pull_request.title: Local time refactor
pull_request.body:
This PR introduces a `DateTimeFormat` ponyfill, which allows us to drop it in place of `Intl.DateTimeFormat`. This then allowed a larger refactor where we can drop parts of the codebase where we emulated `DateTimeFormat` behavior using strftime. Instead, the ponyfill does that and the `relative-time` and `local-time` code can be greatly simplified.

I think in the major version release, we should drop both the `DateTimeFormat` and `RelativeTime` ponyfills as these are very well supported in evergreen browsers. (`DateTimeFormat` works back to IE11 & Safari 10, while `RelativeTime` works back to Safari 14)

pull_request.title: Switch element to defining content within ShadowDOM
pull_request.body:
This changes the `<relative-time>` element to use a ShadowRoot, instead of mutating the `textContent` directly. This is useful because it enables `<relative-time>` to mutate its own display without interfering with components or frameworks which assess or otherwise depend on the tree below `<relative-time>`; for example frameworks like React which maintain a virtual DOM, or code which leverages Mutation Observers to track changes to the tree.

The trade-off here is that it is not possible to assert the display of the date via `el.textContent`, as this would represent the light HTML tree (so likely the original date rendered server side). Consequently the tests need to change to accommodate this.

pull_request.body:
This changes the `<relative-time>` element to use a ShadowRoot, instead of mutating the `textContent` directly. This is useful because it enables `<relative-time>` to mutate its own display without interfering with components or frameworks which assess or otherwise depend on the tree below `<relative-time>`; for example frameworks like React which maintain a virtual DOM, or code which leverages Mutation Observers to track changes to the tree.

The trade-off here is that it is not possible to assert the display of the date via `el.textContent`, as this would represent the light HTML tree (so likely the original date rendered server side). Consequently the tests need to change to accommodate this.
